title: Forge Build is not working
body:
I'm on Ubuntu and have cargo 1.58.0 (7f08ace4f 2021-11-24)  and  rustc 1.58.0 (02072b482 2022-01-11). 
For some reason forge doesn't want to build. Even after I added new tests and changes the contract. 
 It says no files changed, compilation skipped.

When I run forge test it just returns the generic default test which I removed.

For reference I am following this tutorial exactly https://mirror.xyz/sha.eth/6Mn3HjrqKLhHzu2balLPv4SqE5a-oEESl4ycpRkWFsc
Try running with `--force` or running `forge clean` before building. Would also be helpful if we got at least the structure of your project as we have been having some issues with cache invalidation

> Try running with `--force` or running `forge clean` before building. Would also be helpful if we got at least the structure of your project as we have been having some issues with cache invalidation

Doesn't seem to work. I've updated the main issue to show the tutorial i am following. 
But here is the structure. 

```
->src
        ->test
                 ->HelloWorld.t.sol
        ->HelloWorld.sol
```
Just to be clear, is `test` inside of `src`? And do you have any contracts in `src`?

> Just to be clear, is `test` inside of `src`? And do you have any contracts in `src`?

Yes, test is inside of src and src has the contract helloWorld.sol. The test folder has HelloWorld.t.sol. Sorry Idk how to change the formatting here. Again I followed https://mirror.xyz/sha.eth/6Mn3HjrqKLhHzu2balLPv4SqE5a-oEESl4ycpRkWFsc exactly. Does it matter what is inside of lib?

Pretty weird, following that tutorial I get the output I expect:

```
$ forge test
compiling...
no files changed, compilation skipped.
Running 2 tests for HelloWorldTest.json:HelloWorldTest
[PASS] test1() (gas: 4220)
[PASS] test2() (gas: 31425)
```

```
$ tree .
.
├── cache
│   └── solidity-files-cache.json
├── lib
│   └── ds-test
│       ├── default.nix
│       ├── demo
│       │   └── demo.sol
│       ├── LICENSE
│       ├── Makefile
│       └── src
│           └── test.sol
├── out
│   ├── Contract.t.sol
│   │   └── ContractTest.json
│   ├── HelloWorld.sol
│   │   └── HelloWorld.json
│   ├── HelloWorld.t.sol
│   │   └── HelloWorldTest.json
│   └── test.sol
│       └── DSTest.json
└── src
    ├── HelloWorld.sol
    └── test
        └── HelloWorld.t.sol

12 directories, 12 files
```

Could you run the `tree .` command for me? Put the output into quotes like so to keep the indentation:

\```
foo bar
\```

FYI I'm on Linux too (not Ubuntu) so I'd be surprised if it's a platform issue

> Does it matter what is inside of lib?

For that tutorial you *should* have a `ds-test` folder with some files, specifically a `src/test.sol` file (so `lib/ds-test/src/test.sol` should exist).

```
chinmay@chinmay-x1carbon:~/forge$ tree .
.
├── lib
│   └── ds-test
│       ├── default.nix
│       ├── demo
│       │   └── demo.sol
│       ├── LICENSE
│       ├── Makefile
│       └── src
│           └── test.sol
└── src
    ├── Contract.sol
    ├── HelloWorld.sol
    └── test
        └── HelloWorld.t.sol
```

Also when I run sudo forge init I get this :`sudo: forge: command not found`
Yes, that's because `forge` is in `$HOME/.cargo/bin/forge` so that's expected - when you run commands with `sudo` then `$HOME` changes (usually to `/root` or `/home/root`) and it can't find `forge`.
Ok, that looks like it should. Is the source code inside of `Contract.sol` or `HelloWorld.sol`?

> Yes, that's because `forge` is in `$HOME/.cargo/bin/forge` so that's expected - when you run commands with `sudo` then `$HOME` changes (usually to `/root` or `/home/root`) and it can't find `forge`.

Got it. 
But Is it an error with foundry? Why am I not getting an out file

> Ok, that looks like it should. Is the source code inside of `Contract.sol` or `HelloWorld.sol`?

HelloWorld.sol
Can you try to run `RUST_LOG=trace forge test --force` for me and dump the output?

> RUST_LOG=trace forge test --force

```

Running 1 test for ContractTest.jso

Oh, that's weird. It looks like it's compiling contracts in your home folder (you have a `src` folder in your home directory) instead of the project itself. Try removing `$HOME/src` and `$HOME/lib`. Did you accidentally run `forge init` in your home directory? If so, also delete `$HOME/.git`

> Oh, that's weird. It looks like it's compiling contracts in your home folder (you have a `src` folder in your home directory) instead of the project itself. Try removing `$HOME/src` and `$HOME/lib`. Did you accidentally run `forge init` in your home directory? If so, also delete `$HOME/.git`

Ohhh i think I did. Here is what I am etting when I run forge test now. Should I run forge init again?
```
chinmay@chinmay-x1carbon:~/forge$ forge test
Error: 
   0: No such file or directory (os error 2)

Location:
   /rustc/02072b482a8b5357f7fb5e5637444ae30e423c40/library/core/src/result.rs:1911

Backtrace omitted.
Run with RUST_BACKTRACE=1 environment variable to display it.
Run with RUST_BACKTRACE=full to include source snippets.
```
The directories `src` and `lib` still exist in `$HOME/forge` but do not exist in `$HOME` now? It's looking for a directory that is not there now (we are only looking for `src` and `lib`)
It works now! Thanks so much for your time. I really appreciate it.
Thank you for your patience and don't hesitate to report back with any issues you encounter, both bugs and things you think could be improved :smile:

Whoever this helps, in my case the problem was that I committed the repository from one machine, then cloned down from another and could not understand why the lib assets were missing.

The folder `./lib/ds-test` is a git submodule, to get the content after cloning the existing repo execute:

```
git submodule init
git submodule update
```

After this running `forge test` should just work.

Source: https://stackoverflow.com/a/3796947

Two alternatives to that as well:

- `git clone --recursive <your repo>` (also clones submodules)
- `forge install` after cloning :)
